Package org.jtrim2.event

Interface ListenerManager<ListenerType>

Type Parameters:
ListenerType - the type of the event listeners can possibly be added to the container
All Superinterfaces:
ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>, SimpleListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
All Known Implementing Classes:
CopyOnTriggerListenerManager
public interface ListenerManager<ListenerType> extends ListenerRegistry<ListenerType>
Defines a ListenerRegistry which allows events to be dispatched to registered listeners directly.

The listeners can be notified synchronously on any thread and also be provided with a single argument.

Here is a simple usage of this interface assuming Runnable to be a listener: 


 ListenerManager<Runnable, Void> listeners = ...;
 listeners.registerListener(listener1);
 listeners.registerListener(listener2);

 // ...

 // Sometimes later, dispatch the event to "listener1" and "listener2"
 listeners.onEvent((Runnable eventListener, Void arg) -> {
   eventListener.run();
 }, null);
The above code will call the run method of both listener1 and listener2 in the onEvent method. Notice that the EventDispatcher is always the same and as such a single static instance can be created for better performance.

Thread safety

Implementations of this interface are required to be safe to use by multiple threads concurrently.

Synchronization transparency

The onEvent method of this interface does not required to be synchronization transparent but methods inherited from ListenerRegistry are required to be synchronization transparent as specified by ListenerRegistry.
See Also:
  • CopyOnTriggerListenerManager
  • OneShotListenerManager

  • Method Details

    • onEvent

      <ArgType> void onEvent(EventDispatcher<? super ListenerType,? super ArgType> eventDispatcher, ArgType arg)
      Invokes the onEvent method of the specified EventDispatcher with the currently registered listeners and the argument specified. The onEvent method is called synchronously in the current thread.

      Adding new listeners to this container will have no effect on the current call and the listeners being notified. That is, if a notified listener adds a new listener to this container, the newly added listener will not be notified in this call, only in subsequent onEvent calls.

      The order in which the listener are notified is undefined. Also note, that multiply added listener might be notified multiple times depending on the exact implementation.

      Note that usually it is required that event listeners be invoked in the order the events occur. This can easily be done when events can only occur on single thread (as they do in Swing). However, when events can occur on multiple threads concurrently they are likely to occur while holding a lock and listeners should be notified right away to be notified of the event to keep the order of events. Note that calling an event handler method while holding a lock is prone to dead-lock (and it is very likely to be possible since it is hard to reason about what listeners might do). In this case you should consider using a TaskScheduler to invoke the onEvent method.

      Type Parameters:
      ArgType - the type of the argument which is passed to event listeners
      Parameters:
      eventDispatcher - the EventDispatcher whose onEvent method is to be called for every registered listener with the specified argument. The onEvent method will be called as many times as many currently registered listeners are (i.e.: the number the getListenerCount() method returns). This argument cannot be null.
      arg - the argument to be passed to every invocation of the onEvent method of the specified EventDispatcher. This argument can be null if the EventDispatcher allows for null arguments.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified EventDispatcher is null
      See Also:
      • TaskScheduler
